intro: Astragalus riparius, commonly known as the river milkvetch, is a flowering plant native to the temperate regions of the northern hemisphere. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its compound leaves and yellow or pale purple flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, sandy soils along riverbanks and other wetland habitats. Astragalus riparius is known for its ability to fix nitrogen through symbiotic relationships with rhizobia bacteria, contributing to soil fertility. Its ecological importance includes providing nectar for pollinators and serving as a food source for various herbivores.
